Creating topic templates

Parent topic: Working with DITA topics

What is a topic template?

A topic template is a predefined topic layout that you can use as a starting point to create new topics. The template already contains the main elements that you will need in your topic, so you do not have to insert them each time you create a similar topic.

For example, when you create a new topic in Oxygen you have to select the topic template you want to use. By default, Oxygen provides a template for the main DITA information types (Task, Concept, Reference) and some specialized information types (such as Composite and Glossentry). After you have selected a template, Oxygen opens an untitled topic, including the elements that are relevant for the information type you selected.
The specialized information types have the following functions:
  • Composite: The composite topic is a now obsolete tool for collecting multiple topics and nesting them within a single topic file. Using a ditamap is a superior method for collecting topics together, and should always be used in preference to a composite topic.
    Note: Composite still has some use as a container for re-use information, because it allows you to organize snippets of conref source information into a single topic.
  • Glossentry: The glossentry topic is a specialized form of concept, developed to improve glossary and terminology management.

To create a topic template

If a lot of your topics have a similar structure or if the default topic templates do not suit you, you can create your own topic template(s). Proceed as follows:

  1. Create a new topic. While doing so, select the default topic template for the correct information type.
    If you want to create a new template for a task topic, use the default task topic template as a starting point.
  2. Name the new template.
    This name will be displayed in the new document wizard.
  3. Save the new template in a folder _custom_framework.
    Note: This sub-folder is part of the general Flow structure of DITA folders (How is the Flow custom framework built?): _custom_framework > topic_templates.
  4. Delete and insert elements to create the topic layout that you want.
  5. Choose File > Save.
    Note: If you have not yet referenced the location of your templates folder for the specific document type in Oxygen, follow the steps in To reference the location of the templates folder.
